The Love Guru is a 2008 American romantic comedy film directed by Marco Schnabel in his directorial debut, written and produced by Mike Myers, and starring Myers as Guru Pitka.
A flashback shows that Pitka was an orphan, taught by Guru Tugginmypudha.
Guru Pitka is self proclaimed "number-two guru in the world", after Deepak Chopra.

When the twelve-year-old Pitka announces he wants to become a guru so that girls will love him, Tugginmypudha puts a chastity belt on him until he can learn that loving himself is more important than being loved by others.
Pitka asks if he can still masturbate but is warned if he attempts to he  will become blind with strabismus like Tugginmypudha.
After Deepak Chopra.
Coach Cherkov punches Pitka in the testicles, his chastity belt does not protect his genitals and he groans grabbing his crotch and hunching over.
Pitka encourages the rival team to beat Darren up during a game to distract him from his distress over his wife's affair.
Darren beats up Lè Coq
Pitka has dinner with Jane and almost kisses her but his chastity belt clanks again and she leaves feeling rejected.
Since his mother only showed him love when he succeeded, he had grown to believe Prudence would only love him as long as he won.
Pitka distracts Lè Coq with his idol, Celine Dion
Pitka tells Prudence that Darren stood up to his mom, encouraging her to return to her husband
Lè Coq gets Darren's mother to sing the national anthem, causing Darren to flee
Pitka reveals his chastity belt to explain why he pulled away from Jane
Lè Coq brags that Prudence prefers him in bed
Pitka gets two elephants to have sex in the middle of the rink, in front of the live television audience
Lè Coq's brag causes Darren to freeze and enter a stupor

Coach Cherkov apologizes for the groin attack, Pitka offers a hug but as Cherkov obliges he punches him in the face and threatens to beat him up if he ever attacks him again. They then make up and become friends.
Pitka meets Deepak Chopra and decides that he is fine with being the first Guru Pitka instead of the next Deepak Chopra

Character created by Mike Myers

Myers said, "I figure the only way that my team will win a Cup is if I write it."
Film titled The Love Guru.
First time director Marco Schnabel directed the film.
The review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes gave The Love Guru an approval rating of 13%, based on 178 reviews, with an average rating of 3.5/10.
The website's critical consensus reads, "The Love Guru features far too many gross-out gags, and too few earned laughs, ranking as one of Mike Myers' poorest outings."

CinemaScore gave the film a grade 'B -' on scale of A to F.
Gave the film one star and said the film "is shockingly crass, sloppy, repetitive and thin."
Chopra is used almost as a product placement, taking a proud spot alongside a circus, a brand of cinnamon buns, the Leafs and, of course, Mike Myers.
The sitar based versions of pop songs like '9 to 5' are oddly watchable – but mostly the film is 88 minutes of ridiculous sight gags and obscene puns.

node_1: myers' obnoxious attempts to find mirth in physical and cultural differences
edge: The word 'unfunny' surely applies to Mr. Myers's obnoxious attempts to find mirth in physical and cultural differences but does not quite capture the strenuous unpleasantness of his performance. No, The Love Guru is downright antifunny, an experience that makes you wonder if you will ever laugh again.

node_2: gave the film 1 out of 4 stars
edge: Roger Ebert gave the film 1 out of 4 stars,
Every reference to a human sex organ or process of defecation is not automatically funny simply because it is naughty, but Myers seems to labor under that delusion.

node_2: considered the love guru 'one of the worst films'
edge: Harry Knowles of Ain't It Cool News wrote a highly negative review, saying The Love Guru 'isn't merely a bad film, but a painful experience.'

Mick LaSalle of San Francisco Chronicle was one of the few major critics who did not write the film off completely, stating 'Mike Myers's new comedy, "The Love Guru," is a disappointment, but it's not a disaster, and that's at least something.'

The Love Guru, a film, appears to be lampooning Hinduism and Hindus according to Rajan Zed, a Hindu cleric from Nevada. Some Hindus have expressed unhappiness about how Hindus are portrayed in the film, believing it is disrespectful and risks giving Hinduism a bad reputation among viewers not familiar with the faith.
Paramount Pictures, a production company, released The Love Guru.

In an appearance on the December 20, 2014 episode of Saturday Night Live, Myers appeared as Dr. Evil, a character from his far more successful Austin Powers series, giving advice to Sony Pictures on its cancellation of the release of The Interview.
Mike Myers starred in and produced The Love Guru.
Sony Pictures, a production company, canceled the release of The Interview due to security concerns after threats from North Korea.

Paramount Pictures agreed to provide the Hindu American Foundation (HAF) an opportunity to pre-screen the film as soon as it had a complete work print of the film, but ultimately did not follow through with this plan.
Paramount requested representatives of the Hindu American Foundation (HAF) attend a Minneapolis pre-screening the night before the film's release.
Many requests from American Hindus who were concerned about the film.
